title.narrative: Equity and Quality in the Intercultural Education in Puno, Kawsay

description.narrative: In coordination with non-school early childhood education through the government PRONOEI system, CARE provides face-to-face support to teachers and educational promoters once a week. The rest of the week, mothers develop stimulating activities with their children according to training provided by CARE. The program also provides a guide for timely stimulation and records ongoing assessments of participating children's development. The project was scheduled for completion in December 2010 and has been extended through March 15, 2011. With regard to primary school, was scheduled for project completion in December 2010 and was extended until March 15, 2011. Even after I finish the project, CARE continued to visit some of the schools, giving them additional materials for the school, and offering suggestions for the consolidation of changes in schools. For the form of this new phase of the proposed KAWSAY, CARE helped in the development of activities to monitor curriculum development, as measured by student progress.

Promotores educativos iniciaron capacitados en el marco del PCR para el trabajo con niños menores de 5 años.

The “Equity and Quality of Intercultural Education in Puno” Project, KAWSAY II, financed by the Douglas B. Marshall Jr. Family Foundation, was implemented in the Local Education Management Units – UGELs in Azángaro and Melgar in 116 Early Learning Programs (PAOs, for the Spanish acronym) articulated through 116 Non-Formal Early Education Programs (PRONOEIs) and 32 Elementary Schools, including the San Roman UGEL. In this framework, a summary of the activities that were developed is presented at the completion of the project.
